newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Adsteam holders ok maritime float plan.
newsitem.headline: Adsteam holders ok maritime float plan.

text.p: Shareholders in Adelaide Steamship Co Ltd on Wednesday approved the possible float of the company's marine operations.
The extraodinary general meeting also approved a change in the company's name to Residual Assco Group Ltd, allowing the marine division to be called Adsteam Marine if it is floated.
Adsteam chairman Peter Cottrell said after the vote that an overwhelming number of proxies had supported the proposals.
No date was set for the float of the marine division, but further details could be released at a news conference set for 11.30 a.m. (0200 GMT) on Wednesday.
Adsteam said on March 2 that the float could occur before June with the right market conditions but would not comment on media reports that the company would raise up to A$160 million from the sale.
Funds raised would be used to reduce debt.
The maritime unit consisted of an extensive harbour towage and marine services operation in more than 33 Australian ports and another four ports in Papua New Guinea and Fiji.

Adsteam said the unit was Australia's largest marine towage operator with a fleet of 45 vessels, including some owned in joint ventures with Howard Smith Ltd and the Stannard family. The unit's 1995/96 pre-tax operating profit rose by A$4 million to A$19.6 million.
Adsteam was one of Australia's largest corporate failures following the debt binge of the 1980s.

It came under the control of its bank creditors in 1990 with debts of A$11 billion which has now been reduced to less than A$700 million. Woolworths Ltd and David Jones Ltd were once part of the Adsteam group and were floated by the creditors.
